--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <colin.green1@...> wrote:

> Typic=
ally the x,y here could be weightings given to different aspects
> of a fit=
ness function or we could combine two distinct fitness
> functions with wei=
ghts (which amounts to the same thing). So e.g.
> 
>    f(G, x, y) =3D (f1(=
G) * x) + (f2(G) * y)

On relfection this isn't quite right. One weigting w=
ould adjust the balance between two fitness functions, e.g.

    f(G, x) =
=3D (f1(G) * x) + (f2(G) * (1-x))

So for a 2D space you'd have something l=
ike:

    f(G, x, y) =3D (f1(G) * x) + (f2(G) * (1-x)) 
               + (f=
3(G) * y) + (f4(G) * (1-y)) 


We also need a way to make selection not bec=
ome biased towards Individuals in one part of the space because they get be=
tter fitness there - maybe the fitnesses need be normalized in some way (ma=
x in each region is the same) but that doesn't feel quite right (needs more=
 thought).

I'll also give an example of a domain to try and explain why th=
is might work. Consider a fitness function with just 1 dimension f(G,x) and=
 we're tryign to evolve a bipedal walker. f1 could be a standing still test=
 (not falling over), f2 could be the walking distance test. So you're genom=
es start out by doing well on f1 and then some migrate over to f2 to popula=
te that region of the fitness space. It does mean more CPU effort having to=
 evaulate f1 and f2, and you also need to define network inputs such that y=
ou can tell the biped whether to stand or walk, so it's not an entirely tri=
vial swap in replacement of G based fitness sharing, but I'm warming to the=
 idea the more I think about it.

Colin.
